speaker: BUGGER
line: Behold the mighty cockroach. Believed to have originated in the Surilian period over three-hundred and fifty million years ago. They can be found in every part of the world from the tropics to the arctic. There exists four-thousand known species... and in a year, a single female can produce over half a million descendants. Radiation doesn't kill them. By evolutionary standards, they are nearly flawless creatures but creatures nevertheless. Possessing only a simple nervous system, their behavior is dictated solely by responses to environmental stimuli. Unlike us, they are incapable of thought, of... self-illumination. Compared to the roach, we are gods... and must therefore act accordingly.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Is it true if you decapitate them, they continue to live, eventually dying of starvation?

speaker: BUGGER
line: Look, buddy, I just kill them.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Well, that's why I called you. I, I thought that nowadays, you froze the insects to death.

speaker: BUGGER
line: Freeze them? Where's the fun in that? No, we got a new pesticide that works like a fungus. It not only kills the infected roach, but that roach then spreads the disease to every other roach he comes into contact with.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Well, just as long as you, uh, get rid of them. Bugs... I don't know. They drive me crazy.

speaker: BUGGER
line: Why, you arrogant little...

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: I forgot to tell you, I also found a roach on the...

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, where have you been? I've been trying to reach you all day.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, my apartment complex was being fumigated so I thought I'd get away for the weekend. I came up to Massachusetts.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Visiting your mother?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, just, uh... sitting and thinking. Widespread accounts of unidentified colored lights hovering in the skies were reported last night. Look, Scully, I know it's not your inclination but... did you ever look up into the night sky and feel certain that... not only was something up there but... it was looking down on you at that exact same moment and was just as curious about you as you are about it?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I think the only thing more fortuitous than the emergence of life on this planet is that, through purely random laws of biological evolution, an intelligence as complex as ours ever emanated from it. Uh, the, the very idea......of intelligent alien life is not only......astronomically improbable but at it's most basic level, downright anti-Darwinian.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully... what are you wearing? I understand what you're saying, but I, I, I just need to keep looking.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, well, don't look too hard. You might not like what you find.

speaker: MULDER
line: Isn't that what, uh, Doctor Zaius said to Charlton Heston at the end of "Planet of the Apes?"

speaker: SCULLY
line: And look what happened.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, I got to go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wait... Mulder, what's going on? Mulder?

speaker: FRASS
line: How you doing? What are you doing?

speaker: MULDER
line: Just sitting, thinking.

speaker: FRASS
line: Sitting and thinking? And talking on the phone? Who with, your drug dealer? Let me see some I.D. The bureau? You on a case?

speaker: MULDER
line: I heard reports of several UFO sightings in this area last night. You see anything?

speaker: FRASS
line: No, sir, not personally. But we did receive a lot of telephone calls.

speaker: MULDER
line: Any more calls tonight?

speaker: FRASS
line: No, sir. The F.B.I. keeps tabs on these things?

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: FRASS
line: Excuse me, sir, I don't like to pry, but why are you sitting here with your wiper blades on?

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, I was just knocking off some bugs that landed on my... Landed on my windshield.

speaker: FRASS
line: Cockroaches?

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe, maybe beetles. I dunno, I'm not really good with bugs.

speaker: WOMAN ON APB WIRE
line: ...send dispatch unit, over.

speaker: FRASS
line: Sorry to disturb you, sir.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's the matter?

speaker: FRASS
line: Another roach attack.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hello?

speaker: MULDER
line: I think you better get up here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What is it?

speaker: MULDER
line: It appears that cockroaches are mortally attacking people.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm not going to ask you if you just said what I think you just said because I know it's what you just said.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm crouching over a bug exterminator whose recently deceased body was discovered with cockroaches crawling all over him. The local sheriff says that two other bodies were found in the same condition this afternoon.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where are you again?

speaker: MULDER
line: Miller's Grove. It has a large science constituency. The other incidents involved a molecular biologist and an astrophysicist and the witness to this case is an alternative fuel researcher. These reports are not coming from yahoos out in the boondock.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: The image of those cockroaches has been permanently imprinted onto my brain. I see them every time I close my eyes.

speaker: FRASS
line: Try not to close your eyes.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: How am I going to sleep? And where? I'm certainly not spending the night here.

speaker: FRASS
line: Maybe you could get a motel room or something.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Were there insect bites on the body?

speaker: MULDER
line: Insect bites?

speaker: NEWTON
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: No.

speaker: SCULLY
line: 'Cause you know, Mulder, millions of people are actually allergic to cockroaches. There have been reported cases of fatal reactions. It's called, uh, anaphylactic shock.

speaker: MULDER
line: Anaphylactic shock?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mm-hmm. Many such reactions have occurred to entomologists or, uh, exterminators.

speaker: MULDER
line: Okay, we'll check that out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You still want me to come up?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no, no, I'm sure you're right. Thanks, Scully.

speaker: FRASS
line: Who was that?

speaker: MULDER
line: My drug dealer.

speaker: STONER
line: Dude, that's some good crap. Come on, it's your hoot.

speaker: CHICK
line: Um, I don't know about this, you guys.

speaker: DUDE
line: You really ought to, you know. Try it. This stuff takes your mind and just, sort of, you know... expands it.

speaker: CHICK
line: Yeah, well... something tells me it's more than my mind you guys are interested in expanding.

speaker: STONER
line: Well, how about another beer then?

speaker: CHICK
line: Okay.

speaker: DUDE
line: I don't know. I think you're making a mistake here. Beer is just, you know... beer. But this stuff, it like... swings the doors of perception so wide open, you can see whole 'nother world out there. But it's still like this world, you know? It tweaks your mind and does this whole altered state thing to it. And suddenly, you see reality as it, you know... really exists. Oh, God...

speaker: STONER
line: Dude, what's wrong, man?

speaker: DUDE
line: Oh, God! Roaches!

speaker: STONER
line: Dude, you're freaking, man!

speaker: DUDE
line: Roaches! Cockroaches!

speaker: STONER
line: What's wrong, man?

speaker: CHICK
line: Stop it!

speaker: DUDE
line: Get them out of me! Get them out!

speaker: STONER
line: Dude, stop!

speaker: DUDE
line: Get them out!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Stay. Hello?

speaker: MULDER
line: I take it back, Scully, I think you better get up here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Another roach attack?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, and this was no allergic reaction. Two witnesses claim they saw the victim screaming about cockroaches burrowing into him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are there still insects in the body?

speaker: MULDER
line: We haven't located any yet, but there are wounds all over the body.

speaker: SCULLY
line: From the cockroaches?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well... the victim did attempt to extract the insects using a razor blade, but we're not sure all of the incisions are self-inflicted, except for the severed artery.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, was there any evidence of drug use at the crime scene?

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh, well, he did have a homemade lab set up, but I'm not sure what he was producing. Aw, man, smells like a septic tank! Would you make sure this gets analyzed, here?

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, Mulder, there's a psychotic disorder associated with some forms......of drug abuse where the abuser suffers from delusions that insects are infesting their epidermis. It's called Ekbom's Syndrome.

speaker: MULDER
line: Ekbom's Syndrome?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The victim cuts himself in, in an attempt to extract the imaginary insect. Still want me to come up?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, uh, you're probably right. I'm sorry to bother you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's no bother. Bye. Hey!

speaker: FRASS
line: These kids are braindead. I couldn't get anything out of them.

speaker: MULDER
line: How about some urine? For a drug test.

speaker: FRASS
line: Did you get it?

speaker: MULDER
line: Get me a container. Oh, I think I killed it.

speaker: FRASS
line: You killed it? You annihilated it.

speaker: MULDER
line: It must have molted. It's just empty exoskeleton.

speaker: FRASS
line: Well, at least we've got evidence that cockroaches were actually here.

speaker: MULDER
line: We've got more than that, sheriff. I think that bug's exoskeleton was made of metal.

speaker: NEWTON
line: Nothing more than a skin abrasion.

speaker: MULDER
line: An abrasion caused by a metallic substance?

speaker: NEWTON
line: Why don't we wait until the, uh, analysis of the compound is finished before jumping to any conclusions? Uh, Agent Mulder, as a, as a doctor, I always find it best to be... completely honest and open with my patients, no matter how unpleasant the information.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you need to tell me?

speaker: NEWTON
line: No, I need you to tell me something. What the hell is going on here? Wh... are we in any danger?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know.

speaker: NEWTON
line: Well, should I evacuate my family?

speaker: MULDER
line: I wouldn't know.

speaker: FRASS
line: Doc, they're waiting for you to examine the boy's body.

speaker: NEWTON
line: Yeah, uh, as soon I take a little break. Uh, after talking with Agent Mulder here, I suddenly feel slightly constipated.

speaker: FRASS
line: What's his problem?

speaker: MULDER
line: He's upset that I don't know what's going on here.

speaker: FRASS
line: So what the hell is going on here?

speaker: MULDER
line: I see the correlation, but just because I work for the federal government doesn't mean I'm an expert on cockroaches.

speaker: FRASS
line: So you're saying you don't know anything about the government's experiments being conducted here?

speaker: MULDER
line: Experiments?

speaker: FRASS
line: A couple of months ago, an agent claiming to be from the department of agriculture sets up base on a couple of acres across town. Nobody knows exactly what's going on out there. It's top secret, very hush-hush.

speaker: MULDER
line: What are you suggesting?

speaker: FRASS
line: Killer bees were a genetic experiment gone awry, let loose on an unsuspecting populace. Who's to say the government hasn't created a new breed of killer cockroaches?

speaker: MULDER
line: You might want to keep that theory to yourself, sheriff. No need to create a panic.

speaker: MAN
line: Oh! Oh, my God! Somebody help, help, hey!

speaker: FRASS
line: What the hell happened?

speaker: MAN
line: Cockroaches. He was covered in cockroaches.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't see any roaches.

speaker: MAN
line: Well, when I went out to look for help and I came back, they disappeared.

speaker: FRASS
line: Gently... gently...

speaker: MULDER
line: Hmm. He doesn't appear odd in any...

speaker: FRASS
line: Next time, let me handle the roaches.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who died now?

speaker: MULDER
line: The medical examiner. His body was found next to a toilet, covered in roaches. I really think you should come...

speaker: SCULLY
line: A toilet? Check his eyes. Is one of them bloodshot with a dilated pupil?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's probably a brain aneurysm.

speaker: MULDER
line: Brain aneurysm?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Straining too forcefully is very common causation for bursting a brain aneurysm.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, how do you explain the roaches, though?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did you catch any?

speaker: MULDER
line: Almost.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know what to tell you, Mulder. I just hope you're not implying you've come across an infestation of killer cockroaches.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder? I've been doing some research. Back in the mid-'80s, there was a cockroach species previously only found in Asia. And since then, it's made an appearance in Florida. They've now completely established themselves in this country.

speaker: MULDER
line: Do they attack people?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, but they do exhibit behavior different than our domestic breeds. They, they fly for long distances and they're attracted to light.

speaker: MULDER
line: But do they attack people?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm suggesting that what's happening out there might be the introduction to this country of a new species of cockroach... One that is attracted to people.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, that all makes perfect sense, Scully. I don't like it at all. Did you know that the federal government, under the guise as the department of agriculture, as been conducting secret experiments up here?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, you're not thinking about trespassing onto government property again, are you? I know that you've done it in the past, but I don't think that this case warrants...

speaker: MULDER
line: It's too late, I'm already inside.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, what's going on? What do you see?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm a house. It's apparently empty.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What does the place look like?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's a, uh... typical two-story suburban house. Nice big living room, sparsely furnished... Nice carpets... fireplace... Nice kitchen. Modern appliances. Moving walls.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Moving walls?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. They're rippling. Oh! Cockroaches!

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?!

speaker: MULDER
line: Cockroaches. They're everywhere. Ah, I'm surrounded.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, you've got to get out of there right now!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Are you all right? What happened?

speaker: MULDER
line: Flashlight went out...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, what's going on?

speaker: MULDER
line: Got to go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder! Mulder!

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: May I ask why you're trespassing on government property?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm a federal agent.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: So am I.

speaker: MULDER
line: Agent Mulder, F.B.I.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Doctor Berenbaum, U.S.D.A. Agricultural research service.

speaker: MULDER
line: Doctor Berenbaum, I'm going to have to ask you a few questions.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: For instance?

speaker: MULDER
line: What's a woman like you doing in a place like this?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: By studying how insects respond to changes in light, temperature, air currents, food availability, we can determine the best ways to eradicate them.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why all the secrecy about your research? You've got some of the good townspeople suspicious.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: You expect us to advertise that we've intentionally infested a house in their neighborhood with thousands of cockroaches?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah... but those, those cockroaches... are they, uh, a normal species?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: They're a common one.

speaker: MULDER
line: Have you ever come across, uh, a type of cockroach that, uh, is attracted to people?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Most cockroaches have been known to actually wash themselves after being touched by humans.

speaker: MULDER
line: Really. So, you've never seen an instance where a cockroach actually attacks a human being?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Well, there have been cases where a cockroach has crawled into a person's ear or nose.

speaker: MULDER
line: Nose? What, what is that there?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Oh, it's just a pet project of mine. Since an insect's exoskeleton is a dielectric surrounding the conductive medium of its body fluid, when introduced into an electrical field, a brushed discharge will result in a colored flare.

speaker: MULDER
line: What is that supposed to prove?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Well, it's my theory that UFOs are actually insect swarms. I don't know if you know anything about UFOs, but all the characteristics of a typical sighting are shared with nocturnal insects swarming through an electrical air field... the sudden appearance of a colored, glowing light hovering in the night sky, moving in a nonmechanical matter, possibly humming. Creating interference with radio and television signals. Then suddenly disappearing.

speaker: MULDER
line: As, uh... as nocturnal insect swarms. That's, uh... that's fascinating.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Everything about insects is fascinating. They are truly remarkable creatures. So beautiful, and so honest.

speaker: MULDER
line: Honest?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Eat, sleep... defecate, procreate. That's all they do. That's all we do, but at least insects don't kid themselves that it's anything more than that. Does my scientific detachment disturb you?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. No, actually, I, I find it quite refreshing. Not now. You know, um... I have always found insects to be very interesting.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Really?

speaker: REPORTER
line: This is the fifth report of a deceased body being found amongst a hoard of cockroaches, but police are not confirming, at least not yet, that the insects have anything to do with the fatalities. Police have also disaffirmed the rumor that these deaths were the result of an outbreak of the Ebola virus, somehow being spread by infected cockroaches. As for now, these incidents remain under local jurisdiction, but a nurse here did confirm that an F.B.I. agent is on the case. Police are asking that if you see any cockroaches, don't panic. Simply notify the authorities and evacuate the area immediately. Reporting live, this is Skye Leikin for Channel three, nightwatch news.

speaker: WOMAN
line: Then suddenly, there was this terrible crash. You know, you could've been killed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, are you okay?

speaker: MULDER
line: I can't sleep.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened at the U.S.D.A. site?

speaker: MULDER
line: They're conducting legitimate experiments. I met an entomologist, Doctor Berenbaum, who agrees with your theory of an accidental importation of a new cockroach species.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did he give you any idea of how to catch them?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. But she did tell me everything else there is to know about insects.

speaker: SCULLY
line: She? Yeah, did you know that the ancient Egyptians worshipped the scarab beetle and possibly erected the pyramids to honor them, which may be just giant symbolic dung heaps?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did you know the inventor of the flush toilet was named Thomas Crapper?

speaker: MULDER
line: Bambi also has this theory I've never come acro...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who?

speaker: MULDER
line: Doctor Berenbaum. Anyway, her theory is...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Her name is Bambi?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. Both her parents were naturalists. Her theory is that UFOs are actually nocturnal insect swarms passing through electrical air fields.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Her name is Bambi?

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, can I confess something to you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, sure, okay.

speaker: MULDER
line: I hate insects.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, lots of people are afraid of insects, Mulder. It's just a... it's a natural, instinctive.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, no, I'm not afraid of them. I hate them. One day back when I was a kid, I, uh... I was climbing this tree when I noticed this leaf walking towards me. It took forever for me to realize that it was no leaf.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A praying mantis?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, I had a praying mantis epiphany and, as a result, I screamed. No, not... not a girlie scream, but the scream of someone being confronted by some before unknown monster that had no right existing on the same planet I inhabited. Did you ever notice how a praying mantis' head resembles an alien's head? I mean, the mysteries of the natural world were revealed to me that day, but instead of being astounded, I was... repulsed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder... Are you sure it wasn't a girlie scream? What was that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, I got to go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mul... no...

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Did you hear that too?

speaker: RESIDENT #1
line: Came from over there.

speaker: RESIDENT #2
line: What the hell is going on?

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Hello? I, is everything all right in there?

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened now?

speaker: MULDER
line: One of the motel guests died.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I'm coming up there right now.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, I think this man died from simply from a reaction to the cockroaches.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Two cases of anaphylactic shock......in the same day in the same town is highly improbable.

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I... I'm saying that I think this mans imply had a heart attack. Word about the cockroach infestation and the deaths related to it have gotten out and... I think this man simply saw some cockroaches and scared himself to death.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Regardless, Mulder, something strange is definitely going on up there.

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe not. All your conjectures have proved correct. The exterminator did die from anaphylactic shock. The teenage boy did die from self-inflicted wounds and was getting high off methane fumes derived from burning manure. The medical examiner did die from a brain aneurysm.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I still haven't been able to explain the cockroaches at all the sites.

speaker: MULDER
line: Or the fact that their exoskeletons are made of metal.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Metal? What are you talking about? Mulder? Mulder, I'm coming up there.

speaker: MULDER
line: Whatever.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can you tell what kind of cockroach it is?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: I should be able to. The abdomen's still attached and we differentiate species by their genitalia. Oh my God...

speaker: MULDER
line: Is it abnormal?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: I'll say. He's hung like a club-tailed dragonfly. Excuse me.

speaker: MULDER
line: Does it still look unusual?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Well, yes. For an insect genitalia, but maybe not for a microprocessor.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're implying that this insect is mechanical? But what am I supposed to be looking at here? Have, have you ever seen anything like this before?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Only in science journals. I've read about an artificial intelligence researcher who designs robots that resemble and behave like insects. I've never seen them myself, but I've often thought of visiting his lab.

speaker: MULDER
line: He works out of this town?

speaker: MULDER
line: Doctor Ivanov?

speaker: IVANOV
line: Why are you scaring my robots? For decades, my colleagues in artificial intelligence have attempted to create an autonomous robot. By struggling to give their machines a human-like brain, they have failed. A human brain is too complex, too computational. It thinks too much. But insects merely react. I used insects as my model, not just in design but by giving them the simplest of computer programs. "Go to the object. Go away from the moving object." Governed only by sensors and reflex responses, they take on the behavior of intelligence, living beings.

speaker: MULDER
line: So this one is just programmed to head towards any object moving within the field of its sensors?

speaker: IVANOV
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then why is it following me?

speaker: IVANOV
line: He likes you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Your contract is with NASA?

speaker: IVANOV
line: The goal is to transport a fleet of robots to another planet and allow them to navigate the terrain with more intricacy than any space probe has done before. It, it sounds slightly fantastic, but the only obstacle I can foresee is devising a renewable energy source. In any case, this is the future of space exploration. It does not include living entities.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm just speculating here, but if extraterrestrial lifeforms do exist...

speaker: IVANOV
line: Oh, there's no need for speculation, I believe they do.

speaker: MULDER
line: And assuming that they're more technologically advanced than we are, and if your own ideas about the future of space exploration are correct, then...

speaker: IVANOV
line: Then the interplanetary explorers of alien civilizations will likely be mechanical in nature. Yes. Anyone who thinks alien visitation will come not in the form of robots, but of living beings with big eyes and gray skin has been brainwashed by too much science-fiction.

speaker: MULDER
line: Can you identify this?

speaker: IVANOV
line: I'm not really good with bugs. A cricket's legs?

speaker: MULDER
line: Try it under the microscope. Are you all right, Doctor Ivanov? Can you identify that? Sir?

speaker: IVANOV
line: It's... beyond my comprehension.

speaker: MAN #1
line: Hey, kid, move! Gimme that!

speaker: CLERK
line: Hands off, buddy!

speaker: MAN #2
line: Hey, what are you crazy? Watch yourself!

speaker: WOMAN #1
line: Hey, you idiot, you hit me!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Excuse me, do you sell road maps? Could you tell me where they are?

speaker: WOMAN #2
line: Come on, hurry up!

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's going on here?

speaker: WOMAN #2
line: Haven't you heard about the roaches? They're devouring people whole. Everybody's getting the hell out of here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Have you seen any of cockroaches yourself?

speaker: WOMAN #2
line: No, but they're everywhere.

speaker: MAN #3
line: Roaches aren't attacking people, lady. They're spreading the Ebola virus. Look, keep the change. We're all going to be bleeding from our nipples!

speaker: SCULLY
line: All right. All right, listen up! I'm Agent Dana Scully from the Federal Bureau of Investigation. I am assuring you that you are not in any danger. Everything is going to be okay if you just calm down, and start acting rationally. Now, where the hell are those road maps?

speaker: WOMAN #3
line: Hey! This last can is mine!

speaker: MAN #4
line: Roaches!

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, Doctor, I, uh... I appreciate you taking the time to, uh... answer my questions.

speaker: IVANOV
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: Greetings from planet Earth.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Well, it's a cockroach all right. It's not like the leg segment you had me examine earlier. It's just a typical cockroach.

speaker: MULDER
line: Even the...

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Yes, even the genitalia is normal. Cockroaches are common in this area at this time of year. It's one of the reasons I set up my study here.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, this town is insane.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where are you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm in a convenience store on the outskirts of, uh... Civilization. Look, I think I may have a lead. Remember that Doctor Eckerle who was the alternative fuel researcher that witnessed the exterminator's death? Well, the fuel that he's researching is methane gas... methane derived from manure.

speaker: MULDER
line: Manure?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He has an import license......to bring in animal dung samples from outside the country. Now, maybe you can confirm this with your Doctor Bambi......but I think that cockroaches are......dung-eaters, and if so, some of them may have been shipped accidentally in some of the samples. This fuel research facility could be ground zero for the infestation.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, if an alien civilization were technologically advanced enough to build and send artificially intelligent robotic probes to the farthest reaches of space, might they not have also been able to perfect the extraction of methane fuel from manure? An abundant and replenishing energy source filled on a planet with dung-producing creatures.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I think you've been in this town too long.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where's the research facility located?

speaker: MULDER
line: Wait, Bambi. You better wait here until I make sure it's safe.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Well, be careful. We still don't know what these cockroaches are capable of, if they're even cockroaches.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I'm not so much worried about the cockroaches than I am about the human element.

speaker: MULDER
line: Doctor Eckerle?

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: They're after me. First at my house, then at the motel, and then I came here to get away... but... they're following me.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're not in any danger, these insects won't harm you.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: I've seen them kill two men.

speaker: MULDER
line: They weren't responsible for those deaths... but they might be responsible for ours if you continue firing your gun in a plant full of methane gas.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Don't you understand? The bugs... they drive me crazy.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Let me guess... Bambi.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Fox told me to wait out here while he checked inside first. Should I come along with you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No... this is no place for an entomologist.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Why are these roaches making those weird noises?

speaker: MULDER
line: In Madagascar, they have roaches that hiss by blowing air through the holes in their upper thorax.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Really? How, how do you know so much about them?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't. That's why we shouldn't kill these, but capture them for further study. Now, please... put the gun down.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: Have I lost my mind?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. You've just had a very stressful day that's affected your ability to think clearly. Your judgment is a little clouded right now.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: It is? Then how do I know... that you're not a cockroach?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder? Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: I assure you, Doctor Eckerle, I'm just as human as you are... if not more so.

speaker: JEFF ECKERLE
line: You are one of them!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: Get out, Scully! This whole place could blow! Get down! Crap.

speaker: FRASS
line: It's like a crematorium in there, I don't think we're going to locate the doctor's remains.

speaker: MULDER
line: Or anything else, for that matter.

speaker: FRASS
line: Still, it's not as bad as some of the other fires we had last night.

speaker: SCULLY
line: There were others?

speaker: FRASS
line: Four, to be exact. Plus eighteen auto accidents, thirteen assault and batteries, two stores were looted, thirty-six injuries all total, half of them from insecticide poisoning... but, we didn't receive reports on cockroaches or otherwise for the last couple of hours. Maybe this town's finally come to its senses. You two ought to go home and get some rest. You look pooped.

speaker: IVANOV
line: Agent Mulder? They told me I could locate you here. Those, uh, segments you showed me earlier... may I examine them again?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, they're completely desiccated... just like the molted exoskeleton.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: You know, many insects don't develop wings until their last molting stage. Perhaps whatever these things were, they had their final molt and have flown off back to wherever they originated.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, that would explain everything.

speaker: IVANOV
line: May I borrow this, Agent Mulder, for further study?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I've already had a similar sample analyzed, it's nothing but common metals. What do you hope to find from it?

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: His destiny.

speaker: IVANOV
line: Isn't that what Doctor Zaius said to Zira at the end of "The Planet of the Apes?"

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: It's one of my favorite movies.

speaker: IVANOV
line: Mine too. I love science fiction.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: I'm also fascinated by your research. Have you ever considered programming the robots to mimic the behavior of social insects like ants or bees?

speaker: IVANOV
line: As a matter of fact, I have.

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: You know, I read in November of '94 in "Entomology Extreme..."

speaker: IVANOV
line: Oh, I remember that...

speaker: BAMBI BERENBAUM
line: Your article about the pollination of...

speaker: IVANOV
line: Yes, I really enjoyed writing about that...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Smart is sexy. Well, think of it this way, Mulder. By the time there's another invasion of artificially-intelligent, dung-eating robotic probes from outer space, maybe their uber-children will have devised a way to save our planet.

speaker: MULDER
line: You know, I never thought I'd say this to you, Scully... but you smell bad.

speaker: MULDER
line: The development of our cerebral cortex has been the greatest achievement of the evolutionary processes. Big deal. While allowing us the thrills of intellect and the pangs of self-consciousness, it is all too often overruled by our inner, instinctive brain, the one that tells us to react, not reflect, to run rather than ruminate. Maybe we have gone as far as we can go, and the next advance, whatever that may be, will be made by beings we create ourselves using our own tech... Tech... Technology, lifeforms we can design and program not to be ultimately governed and constricted by the rules of survival. Or perhaps that step forward has already been achieved on another planet by organisms that had a billion years head start on us. If these beings ever visited us, would we recognize what we were seeing? And upon catching sight of us, would they react in anything but horror at seeing such mindless, primitive, hideous creatures?
